item.title: Inside the Go CPU profiler
item.description: Go is one of its kind when it comes to profiling. It includes powerful and opinionated(!) profilers inside the runtime. Other languages like Ruby, Python, or Node.js, contains profilers or a few APIs for writing profilers. But they are limited in scope compared to what Go offers out of the box. If you want to learn more about the types of observability tools that Go provides, I highly recommend Felix Geisend√∂rfer’s The Busy Developer’s Guide to Go Profiling, Tracing and Observability

item.title: Improve zsh startup time via lazyload
item.description:
My shell is slooow!

This is my first blog post for years. I have been finding excuses for not writing one over the years, but I feel this is the right time.

I was coding as usual when I started something odd with my shell. I have done few adjustments to my .zshrc file and out of a sudden it became very slow to spawn a new shell. As a person who has a obsession with performance, it became my duty to find out the problem.
